Posts.Content: On Feb 24, 2012 12:02 AM jojosolomon wrote: is there a shampoo or cream that you could rub in your hair prior to chemo to prevent hair loss? if so; what is it and where can i ger it? really in need of assistance on this. Please and thanks guys Sorry, but it's not that simple. The chemo drugs are very strong/toxic and designed to destroy bad cells and it just takes it's tool on nice little hair follicles. I have seen hundreds of cases where I volunteer and what I always advise, is not to shave your head but only cut your hair short enough so a wig will fit better. You need to wait to see how you do. Not everyone looses their hair or maybe it will just be thinning out. I would start to investigate wigs that look like your real hair. The wigs now a days are very, very good. The hair is just beautiful and fine. Here are all my personal notes: http://liveforeverwithcancer.com/ Please write, this community will take care of you and give you great love and support. My Best to You John

Posts.Title: Diagnosed an hour ago -- IDC

Posts.Content: On Jan 06, 2012 12:56 AM Verna wrote: I have decided to go with the mastectomy rather than another lumpectomy.  This is not a recurrence but the two lumpectomies didn't get all margins and additional lump found in second lumpectomy.  This all started in August of 2011.  My surgeon and oncologist decided to try chemo first after 2nd lumpectomy and a mastectomy after.  Then the surgeon came up with the 2 options after the chemo.  After much thought it seems foolish to me to get a third lumpectomy only to worry about what is left in the piece of breast that is left.  I am scheduled for surgery Jan. 13 and will know a week later what was found in the breast.  I'm hoping the chemo took care of any margins.  Thanks for your input.  Mine is stage 1, grade 3, triple negative.   Verna I have 14 aunts and uncles, father and mother all have/had cancer. My mother is 95 she has had different kinds three times. She has had a radical Mastectomy several years ago for reasons very similar to yours. In fact most of my aunts have had radical Mastectomies or problems like yours. I had a cousin in California (65yrs old )that passed away last year from Breast cancer. Her two daughters were in their 30's tested positive for the gene that causes BC and they both had Radical Mastectomies when nothing was wrong just so they would not have to deal with all the problems BC could cause. I support your decision and pray for your speedy recovery. All my personal notes are here: http://liveforeverwithcancer.com/ My LFWC Facebook Link John
